TopicTitle: Russian super heavy rocket program indefinitely postponed

Articles.Content:
There's no money Vasily, no money...

In all seriousness though, no more moon program or deep space program. Or anything for that matter.
Like Angara 7 was ever taken seriously...

> 
> Like Angara 7 was ever taken seriously...

Actually Angara-7 was only one of the proposals, there were a few others as well.
You can assemble a Moon mission with multiple launches.

> 
> You can assemble a Moon mission with multiple launches.

But that becomes tedious and complex when your largest rocket can only carry 25 tonnes, you will need at least 3 rockets but most likely 4 and then theirs the launch rate problem, everything has to be fired within a few days.
With the political situation at russia at the moment, I am not surprised.
Either way it wouldn't matter, their's no money for the PPTS let alone a lunar lander. There's not even enough money for the robotic lunar missions.
Big surprise there...Who would pay for such rocket, and who would pay for payload for her?

> 
> With the political situation at russia at the moment, I am not surprised.

Yes, now is the time of the loyal engineers to ask "who is to blame?".

> 
> But that becomes tedious and complex when your largest rocket can only carry 25 tonnes, you will need at least 3 rockets but most likely 4 and then theirs the launch rate problem, everything has to be fired within a few days.

Not necessarily, you can launch and as you launch earlier payloads can assemble, then launch humans and join up. The only exceptions would be if you used liquified fuels. low orbit decay rates are pretty predictable. The other thing is if you can collaborate with another struggling space program, you can join payloads in space.

I expected this to happen, but not anything like this soon-they hadn't even formally selected a rocket. It's probably a good thing for the program that there are now people in place willing to make these tough decisions-Koptev in particular.
This is no surprise in the current situation. Where did you read it?

> 
> This is no surprise in the current situation. Where did you read it?

Multiple articles, it was the head of Roskosmos decision.

More info here: [http://sen.com/news/russia-puts-off-super-rocket-focuses-on-angara-upgrades](http://sen.com/news/russia-puts-off-super-rocket-focuses-on-angara-upgrades)

In better news the Angara-5 will be receiving an hydrolox upperstage increasing it's LEO tonnage to 35 tonnes.
